Explanation: The doctor suggested 'Inspection of the knee joint for swelling, deformity, or discoloration,' which is similar to the provided step of visually assessing for swelling, redness, or deformity in the right knee.

The doctor suggested 'Palpation of the knee joint to check for tenderness, warmth, or abnormal masses,' which closely aligns with the criteria of checking for warmth, tenderness, or palpable abnormalities.

The doctor suggested a 'Range of motion assessment of the knee joint (active and passive)' which aligns with the goal of evaluating the extent of movement and identifying limitations or pain during flexion and extension.
The doctor did not suggest a specific test similar to the Lachman test with the same justification regarding the integrity of the ACL.
The doctor did not suggest the McMurray test or any similar assessment specifically aimed at evaluating for meniscal tears.
The doctor did not suggest any physical examination step that specifically assesses the integrity of the lateral and medial collateral ligaments through Varus and Valgus stress tests.
The doctor did not suggest a physical exam step similar to the 'Patellar tap test' or provide a justification related to checking for knee effusion.

The doctor suggested 'Assessment of gait and weight-bearing ability,' which aligns with the purpose of gait analysis to observe the patient's walking pattern and identify any compensatory mechanisms due to knee pain.
The doctor did not suggest an examination of the contralateral knee, which is necessary to compare with the affected knee for asymmetries.
The doctor did not suggest a neurovascular examination of the lower limb, which is necessary to assess for any neurovascular compromise associated with the knee injury.
